climbs.name: To Bolt or Not to Boulder

content.description: Start sitting down and left on a triangular flat jug with and a decent crimp in the seam. Use some holds in the seam to gain a foot long rail with a bolt on it. From there continue right on some sidepulls and edges and top out easily with a nice slot at the lip.I spent a good chunk of time cleaning the mud and choss off so the holds don't feel like they're going to break off anytime soon; that said these boulders also fell a thousand feet down so who knows. I tried.Probably goes at C1 using the bolts.
content.location:
In a nook facing away from the road in the main cluster of fallen boulders

 You'll know you're there because there are 2 bolts on the face, 1 is 6 inches below a large rail.

content.description:
Sit-start the steep overhanging prow matched on a comfy finger bucket. Smack up to some slopers on the arete and then fire out right to a good finger-lock on the face. From here keep it together and continue smacking up to glassy slopers and somehow manage to get on top of the block.

 There may be some hidden holds over the lip.Starting lower on a low left hand sloper and reaching up to right hand sloping pocket-like hueco adds a few fun slap moves, body tension and hard move to a jug and a foot cut. The low is likely a grade or two harder.
content.location:
Locate the boulder with the bolts. With the bolts in front of you, enter the corridor to the left and this problem will be on the adjacent boulder inside the cave. It climbs the obvious prow.

 From the small parking lot with the small landslide boulder, walk down the road a few hundred feet to where the new patch of asphalt is. (This is where a boulder landed in the road.) From here follow the trail right up the hill. This trail should lead you to the boulder cluster with this problem on it.

content.description: Stand start the left side of the short overhanging wall on the downhill side of the Bolted Boulder. The start holds are a pair of opposing sidepulls. The right hand is found just to the left of the flat horizontal sloping shelf feature, and the left hand is found out left and is only good for for a finger or two but with a nice thumb catch. Figure out how to get onto the wall and smack up to a nice meathook over the lip. Once here, figure out how to press it out onto the slab and take it to the top.
content.protection: Two pads. Spotter. One may dry fire off the start holds or punt the mantle.
content.location: This problem is found just right of the small cave created between the Bolted Boulder and a smaller block. Just left of the sloping horizontal shelf which is "Onix".

content.description: Stand start with two opposing sidepull slopers on the lip of the short steep overhang. Find a foot to pull on with and figure out how to gain the slab and take it to the top.  There is a sloping gaston hold directly next to a large juggy gaston hold that may prove useful.
content.protection: 2 pads. the top is tall but not too difficult.
content.location: This problem is found in the middle of the downhill overhang of the Bolted Boulder. this is the stand start to "The Chateau".

content.description: Sit or squat start with both hands on the sloping rail. Find some feet and huck to slopers on the lip. A delicate and balancy match leads to a hard mantle onto the slab. Once on the slab, work your way up into easier terrain.
content.location: This problem is found on the large boulder with the bolts on it. It is located on the short overhanging side opposite of the bolted side.

content.description: Stand start on two good edges and dyno up to a jug. Match the jug, then reach good holds on the lip and top out. Moving out right to the arete and finishing up that is a grade easier.
content.location: This problem is on the right side of the clean uphill overhang of the Bolted Boulder.

content.description: Start with a right hand rail above the lip of the overhang and left hand on a good undercling on the overhang. Find some feet, pull on and move up to some slopers and crimps before a tricky mantle onto the slab.
content.protection: 2 pads. The top out is still a bit sandy and dirty, but there a good holds.
content.location: The right side of the short overhang. This climb is on the opposite side of the boulder as the two bolts.

content.description: Sit start with a left hand sidepull undercling and a slopey right hand edhe. Find a foot, pull on and dyno to the lip. Match then figure out how to top out on glass.
content.location: This problem is found on the same boulder as the two bolts. From the two bolts walk left through the corridor and this problem is found. It is also located just behind/ next to "Stevie Nicks".

content.description: Sit start the short steep overhang with a left hand 1 pad three finger edge and right hand on a sidepull rail. Figure out some tricky footwork and fire up to a big blind hold above the lip. Latch this, then figure out the topout on the fly.
content.protection: 3 pads. It is a bit of a blind huck for the meathook.
content.location: This problem is on the Bolted boulder on the downhill side, found on the short, steep, friction dependent overhang. It is the leftmost problem on the overhang and possibly the most obvious.

content.description: alt start of TBoNTB.start sitting with a good undercling to move into the rail and into edges.Sit starts are R A D
content.location: Find the bolts, find the underclings

content.description: Sit start on some diagonal holds. Pull on and move out left to a slopey hold, then figure out how to cross over to the bucket on the lip. Match, then figure out how to top out.
content.location: This problem is found to the right of "Stevie Nicks". You start sitting on the fallen tree pretty much.

content.description: Start as for Fleetwood arete and go left into the face. Use any combo of solid jugs/crimps to top out.Â
content.location: Just to the right of Fleetwood Mac, same start as for Fleetwood Arete.

content.description: Start sitting with a left hand Gaston right hand jug. Pull on, try not to dab the fallen tree(s), and follow the arete up. Fun, easy movement and a good warm up for the landslide area.Â Not sure if this has been done before, it was pretty dirty and chossy when I was cleaning it.
content.location: On the Arete to the right of Fleetwood Mac, it is right next to the trail when you first walk up from the road.

content.description: Stand start the smooth subtle overhang with a good right hand edge and a gaston crystal for the left. Find some feet to pull on with then execute a big lock-off cross to a bitey edge. From here pull through to a nice jug, then move left on jugs to execute a fun mantle or exit right for a less inspiring and appealing exit.This problem is a slight variation of "No Doubt" that climbs well and independently.Â
content.protection: 2 pads. Landing drops a foot or two to the left.
content.location: This problem is found on the uphill overhang of the large Bolted Boulder. It is to the right of the dyno, "Before the Storm", and uses the left hand start hold of "No Doubt" except for the right hand.It starts standing on the log landing with its drop being on the mind.

content.description: Start matched on a pinch on the right arete. Get the big right foot and make a big right hand move to the sloping crimp/slot. Move up and top out. Crux is getting yourself established and pulling off the ground.
content.location: On the same boulder with the bolts on the right arete if you are looking at the bolted face.Â

content.description: Squat start with a sloping pinch and a slightly bitey gaston-like edge. Figure out a tricky foot and power up to the lip with either hand, keep the tension and blast up with the other hand. Stand up on a foot and go for a set of opposing gastons on the slab then top out the tall slab in easier terrain.
content.protection: 2 pads. Falls can be a bit violent even though the crux is only a few feet from the ground.
content.location: This boulder problem is found on the downhill side of the Bolted Boulder. It is found just right of the obvious horizontal sloping shelf which is "Onix".

content.description: Stand start the overhang with a sidepull crimp and a nice sloping blob for the right. Pick some feet and dyno to the arete.Â Figure out how to match, then, instead of topping out straight up, bust out right to a sloper, then a nice sloper gaston. These slops eventually lead to a series of victory buckets to the apex of the overhang where a glorious jug awaits, allowing for an easy, full value mantle a few feet off the deck.
content.protection: 3-4 pads and a spotter. The sloper section may very well be the crux of the climb.
content.location: On the uphill side of the Bolted Boulder. This problem is a better, more full value experience than "Before the Storm".Â

content.description: Stand start the tall overhang with a sloping right hand hold and a left hand crimp sidepull found down and to the left. Find some feet and pull on to the wall. A hard full span move out left gains a large sidepull/ dihedral. Figure out how to match then continue straight up to a tricky and sloping top.
content.protection: 3 pads. Swing is hard to hard and the top isn't easy
content.location: This boulder problem is found on the tall, almost blank uphill overhanging face of the large boulder with the bolts.

content.description:
Yes, this boulder used to be home to a sport climb. Yes there are bolts on it, and they are upside down. 

  This is a giant boulder that is home to a large quantity of climbs. It has a few easy slabs that face the road, some super slopey and powerful short overhanging one-move wonders all around V8-V10 side by side, a bunch of climbs ranging V2-V6 in a variety of styles from dynos, mantles, traverses, powerful aretes, crimp climbs and burly undercling problems. 

  This is a great boulder that is worth several visits. Most of the landings are fairly safe with a few crash pads. There are several ways to downclimb the boulder as well. 

  This area also is home to the adjacent block that also has some great climbs, including the steep overhanging prow "Stevie Nicks".
